text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but it can be effective against the cancer. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, I personally tend to use chemotherapy later than most of the people. Uh, and part of the reason for that is because we have a lot of trials which, you know, we believe in, of course, because they’re our studies. And we have best of interest in them. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And we have laboratory research on those things, so we are excited, you know – Patient: Um hum. Doctor: - to go to humans, human trials, but, uh, unless, unless your pain is getting substantially worse, in which case I would strongly encourage you to do the chemo, because that’s going to work the fastest. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Unless the pain is clearly getting worse, and if I feel that we have like a window of opportunity, where, you know, maybe the hasn’t worked but your cancer is not bad enough that you need chemotherapy right this second, then that might be like an opportunity to try a second trial. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: But if I truly believe that this pain is escalating or you’re having, you know, more bad days than good days, or, you know, you’re really not able to sleep for more than like an hour at a time because you’re waking up because of back pain, those types of things would certainly lead me towards maybe chemotherapy as the next step, and perhaps reserving that clinical trial for after the chemotherapy is over.

text: Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: and that came back as positive. So some transcripts are negative and some transcripts are positive. But that’s generally considered a positive test, which is a negative thing. Patient: Oh (chuckles) Doctor: And we tried to get your tissues set out for genetic testing, and it wasn’t enough or inadequate for them to run any tests on it. So we don’t have any more data about molecular testing. Dr. G mentions it in his note as well that that’s something that he wants to do. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I don’t know where he is with that as to whether he’s going to try a different company or other tissue that he may have. And I don’t know what they sent. Did they send the tissue from your liver or tissue from back when you were first diagnosed? Patient: I don’t know. Doctor: I don’t know either. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: They just said it was inadequate. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: So we don’t have any results about are there gene studies that you could go on. Uhm, so the ARV7 positive means that you know your cancer is pretty smart and knows how to grow despite testosterone being low, despite being on drugs like the Zytiga or the Xtandi, and that really you know as I said last time, at some point we have to decide when your cancer is worse. I tend not to rely on PSA. Patient: Mm.

text: Patient: Do you know that for sure? Doctor: Were married to people in England, had children in England. So, I’m English, right? And, then, my moth --- my grandmother’s German. My grandfather is English. So I’m going to do my Ancestry.com just to confirm, um, you know, those are my things. Family Member: I betcha you’re German, like us, yeah. Doctor: No English. I don’t even know how it’s possible because Doctor: It came back, like, I was German. My mother is Italian. That was there. The German was there, but it didn’t even mention English. And then, there was a little note, saying, “A low probability, four percent, English.” Like, no, that’s impossible because, English, English, English, English. Doctor: I see all of this, and I’m like, hmmm, I wonder if one of my great grandfathers is not English. (Laughs) Patient: He might have been a Norman. Doctor: He might have been! Patient: Which would be worse than anything. Doctor: Maybe they were, yeah. I don’t know. No, I think, that’s French, right? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: No, I don’t have any French. Doctor: I had some Spanish-Portuguese, maybe

text: Patient: So when you say three so what we determined so far is that it – it’s in one lymph node, so. Doctor: It’s possible that as part of this trial if you decide to look into it more – PAT; Um, hum. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: PSMA stands for prostate-specific membrane antigen. It’s a protein that sits on the cell membrane, on the surface of the cancer cell – Patient: Okay. Doctor: - and if you can imagine if you have radioactive molecule that binds which to your protein that’s found on the cell surface of your cancer cell and that can be used to um uh produce a picture like a light bulb, bright area of light, that we um – that we can sometimes pick up cancer that cannot be seen on a conventional CT scan or conventional bald scan . So it’s possible with that kind of scan we might find more than one spot. Patient: Okay. Doctor: We might find two, three spots. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Perhaps lymph nodes, which could be hidden or camouflaged with a conventional CT scan. But everything up to three we will be able to do stereotactic radiation for each of the three metastases. Because more than three then we feel it’s beyond the scope of this trial, it also becomes um less feasible and less practical to target five, six, seven spots. Patient: So at the beginning of the trial you’ll do that scan and that will determine whether I’ll stay in the trial if it’s three or less? Doctor: I believe that the PSMA Pet scan is optional. It’s something that they will discuss with you-

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
